content.description:
This is a left to right traverse across the Crag 3 slab. I thought this would be a fun idea to try out, so figured I'd give it a go.

 Start at the climber's left edge of Crag 3. Climb straight up the path of least resistance to gain the nice ledge. Traverse the ledge to climber's right, passing a vertical crack, and step down to the next ledge. At the end of the ledge, continue up the ramp that brings you to the "Perfection" route crack. Here, exit the ramp by crossing over the "Perfection" route crack and onto the slab. Continue traversing right on the slab and crossing over the "Blueberries" route cracks. Start trending upwards passing the small, curving crack (tricky gear, I got a black tricam in), and head for the right side of Crag 3. Finish by heading straight up a few steps to the top right corner of Crag 3.
content.location: Start at the climber's left edge of Crag 3.Â

content.description: This is a great low angle crack located on Crag 3. Start right beneath the longest crack located in between two smaller cracks to the left and right. A few moves will get you into the crack, and then it's smooth sailing from there.
content.protection: I free soloed this route, but there are plenty of options for protection. I'll lead it next time I'm there and update.
content.location:
Located at Crag 3, this is the leftmost climb. Find the largest crack located between two smaller cracks (see picture).  

  Descent: walk off to the left or the right, although I found the left to be easier and quicker.

content.description: Make some friction moves over a vertical seam positioned between two horizontal cracks that won't take gear. Then climb straight up through a curving/slanting crack near the top.  The  climbing gets progressively easier toward the top.
content.protection: Toprope this with a tree anchor.
content.location: This ascends the right side of Crag 3. Look for the vertical seam between two horizontal cracks on the lower half of the route. The "curving crack" is near the top.

content.description: The crack about 5' right of Perfection, this begins about 15' off the deck and runs to the top. Start on friction moves, and then run up the crack.  Ample foot placements are found on either side of the crack. Too easy? Try smearing your feet for more of a challenge.
content.protection: Stoppers and cams (1 - 1.5") or toprope with a tree anchor.
content.location: In the middle of Crag 3, look for the broken crack right of Perfection - it is hard to miss.

content.description: This is the farthest right route that climbs the marginally steeper section of this face.  Climb through two horizontal cracks, and follow a shallow/vegetated crack toward the top. It is laughable to say this climb  even slightly resembles the fine granite offerings in Squamish, British Columbia...perhaps "squaw" was used as a derogatory term?  This route is perhaps the least memorable of all the easy offerings on this face.
content.protection: Toprope with the tree or a gear anchor. It protects well with smaller nuts and cams up to 1".
content.location: This route is the farthest right at Crag 3. It starts on the hiking trail (i.e., easy scramble) that leads to the top of the cliff. Look for the two horizontal cracks at the start of this climb, and stay far right all the way to the top.

content.description:
This is a 25 foot tall crag that faces east.  You need pro for anchors.  There is broken scrambling it its left side. 

  L->R: 

  A. Perfection, 1, 1p, 25', TR or gear.   B. Blueberries, 2, 1p, 40', TR or gear.   C. Curving Crack, 2, 1p, 35', TR.   D. Squamish Squaw, 3, 1p, 20', TR or gear.
